title: What are some concerns with genetically modified organisms and food? If GMO food has the potential to dramatically increase our food production, why is it so bad? - Quora

Most science-based anti-GMO claims are based on potential threat. That maybe the GMO food will be bad for people, maybe it will be bad for the environment, etc. While potentials always exist,  assuming all GMO's will be dangerous has no basis in scientific fact.  The technology of GMO is perfectly safe, and all GMO crops produced so  far are safe for human consumption and have no negative effects. Claims  of allergenicty or human disease caused by living near GMO crops have all  been disproven. Of course, it is possible to create a GMO food that is  hazardous to human health… and testing by food regulatory industries  will quickly show this to be the case and that product will never be  sold. Scientists agree that any genetically modified products  should be tested individually, on their own merits. Saying all GMO's are  bad because one type can cause allergies is like saying all fruits and  vegetables are bad because some cause allergies, or all cars are bad  because one make and model was faulty. It doesn't make sense. Blanket  bans or labeling of GMO products thus are not supported by food  scientists and biologists. However, the social-science arguments against GMO's are less easily  disproven. There is concern over how the companies that make GMO crops  handle their products and patents, how the crops will affect poor  farmers, etc. Currently (2013), over 75% of all GMO farmers in the world  are small farmers in developing countries, so the claim that GMO is bad  for the poor has been disproven. The claims that GMO's will fight  poverty and hunger, however, haven't been supported either, because so  far the GMO crops are designed for Western markets. We have corn and soy  that require less labor to grow and carnations that are blue, but what  the developing world needs is crops like sorghum and millet that are  drought resistant, for example. Some people worry that using GMO's will  reduce the biodiversity of our agriculture, which is a legitimate  concern, but it is debatable whether biodiversity will be as helpful as  GMO crops in reducing hunger, etc. Some people disagree over the  environmental cost or benefit of GMO's. For example, herbicide-resistant  plants lead to more herbicide usage, which is bad for the environment.  On the other hand, insect-resistant plants lead to less insecticide,  which is great for the environment. Again, being blindly anti-GMO is  illogical. One must study each gene and each crop individually, which  takes a lot of time and effort. Other concerns are humanities ones. Some say GMO tech is playing God,  and reject GMO's on religious grounds. Others say the food is more  "fake," even though humans have been manipulating the genetics of our  food for millennia. Some reject GMO's because they are anti-technology  or pro-organic food, even though feeding 7 billion people on organic  crops only is impossible.  Ultimately a big problem with the anti-GMO movement is that it is  largely among wealthy or otherwise food-secure people, like Europeans  who have plenty of access to lots of healthy food. Here is the key  point: Most anti-GMO activists don't stand to benefit from GMO crops, and can afford to be anti-GMO. It's easy to say "why eat GMO rice with extra vitamin A when you can eat  kale and sweet potatoes that naturally have vitamin A?" if you are a  wealthy Westerner, but much of the world can't afford those crops, nor are they available all  year round. The science is irrelevant to these activists, and their activism is  unethical because they are making descisons for people with no access to  supermarkets or organic food Co-ops based on their own biases. The  people who stand to benefit from GMO crops are those who support their  use… unfortunately much of the developing world trades to Europe, and  their governments are enacting anti-GMO laws not due to science, but out  of economic concerns that Europeans will boycott their goods. The GMO  issue is complex and has many factors, and the economic and social science ones are more important. From a biological standpoint, however, the conclusion is clear. There is nothing inherently dangerous with eating a genetically modified plant relative to a conventional plant. Each trait must be analyzed alone, and the regulation on GMO's is so  intense in nations like the USA that GMO crops will arguably be safer  than conventional products or organics. N Biotechnol, 2010. 27(5): p. 609-13.Qaim, M., The Economics of Genetically Modified Crops. Disclosure: I do not work for any biotech or food companies, I am not  paid by any biotech or food companies, etc. I am a rational scientist  who looks at the facts from scientific literature, not from biased  sources of any kind. I am also, conveniently, currently working on a  debate on GMO's to be held at the Entomological Society of America 2013  meeting, where my team has been assigned to be anti-GMO, so I've read the literature from both sides and make my decisions accordingly.
